Just a nitpick, but I'd call this just closed.
I don't think we want to log and swallow the exception here. I would remove the catch - it's a RuntimeException and if it happens let it flow out.
If the CoreSession was already closed (we didn't initiate the close here so closeInitiated is still false), then closing would throw an ISE because we have already been closed.
But this is more of an issue on the jetty API case where the close signature does not throw any exceptions.

@lachlan-roberts concurrent closes should not throw IMHO, nto even from core. They are possible and they are not rare at all, so I'd rather fix core to not throw ISE on concurrent closes, but just make it idempotent (i.e. no operation if already closed).
See above, just closed.

Please add a test where 2 closes are performed from 2 different threads. The path I would like to be tested is:
Thread T1 calls close() triggering abnormal close so that onWebSocketClose() gets called.
In onWebSocketClose() spawn a new thread T2 that calls close() and wait for T2 to finish.
Expect T1 to finish (was deadlocking before).
added another test for this below here testSecondCloseFromOnClosedInNewThread

The use of the SharedBlockingCallback provided both mutual exclusion (waiting for a previously allocated blocker) as well as the BlockingCallback itself.
It turns out that the mutual exclusion is vulnerable to reentrancy, so that if the blocking operation calls another operation that needs the same SharedBlockingCallback, then we get deadlock.
We have seen that close can have that reentrant behaviour, as it calls user code, but I'm not sure that means we should give up on the mutual exclusion elsewhere.  For example are we sure we can allow two threads to simultaneously enter sendBinary?
Thus I'm not sure we should swap out all the SharedBlockingCallbacks, specially as we don't really know where else this reentrancy might be a problem.  So I think we need to at least modify SharedBlockingCallback to detect such reentrancy and to either do an ISE or perhaps optionally provide a non shared instance.   Perhaps in the methods we know that might be reentrant, we can pass in an extra arg to say that renentrancy is supported:
        try (SharedBlockingCallback.Blocker b = session.getBlocking().acquire(true))	

In this case, if the Blocker is already allocated, then we simply return a new instance that is never shared.

Adding locks would return the mutual exclusion, but I'm kind of concerned that we've never noticed that SharedBlockingCallback is not reentrant before.
So I'd rather fix SharedBlockingCallback to a) detect and warn of such reentrancy; b) to handle it by providing a non-shared version.  That way we would not need to change code in many places.

Why do we need this mutual exclusion for things like sendBinary I can't see why there is any advantage to this over letting core handle it.
With only using the BlockingCallback the entry gets queued in the WebSocketCoreSession flusher and then the thread blocks on the Callback until the frame is sent.
With the SharedBlockingCallback the thread blocks trying to get the Callback itself, then when it gets the callback it can give it to the CoreSession it goes in the flusher and we block on the Callback again.
It wouldn't take more memory to just put the frame in the flusher queue.

Chatted to @sbordet  about this.
We kind of arrived at the conclusion that the websocket code doesn't need mutual exclusion, so your approach of avoiding using SharedBlockingCallback is good... especially as jetty-9 doesn't mutually exclude and just throws a pending exception. We should probably review it's usage everywhere... but that's another issue!
However, we probably do need your BlockingCallback to have an idleTimeout mechanism to avoid waiting forever if the callback fails
SharedBlockingCallback has an idle timeout so we avoid waiting forever.

In practice it seems to not have one set.
See #3279 and #2061

Does SharedBlockingCallback have an idle timeout? I can't see it or how to use it.
But I will try adding one to BlockingCallback.
if the idle timeout is 0, this is wrong.  You should only +1000 to timeouts >0
oops yep I'll fix

Just because I'm paranoid, I think this constructor should be eliminated.
And any setting for "infinite" or "no-timeout" should also be eliminated.

Brace at end of line?

I don't understand this change? try-with-resources seems the right thing to do here.
Why did you keep the blocks if you are not using try-with-resources?

The close says it should throw IOException, so if we have a closed channel it throws ClosedChannelException, and because we are already explicitly closing the try-with-resources just always fails.
I can re-structure the code to remove the blocks.
But in a double close() the second should be a no-op, no? Only in core it throws, but this is javax.
The signature javax close signature declares we throw IOException.
This test should block and wait for the thread (and therefore the close()) to finish, and then return from onWebSocketClose(). In this way we guarantee that we don't deadlock.

nodes.bodyText: Why shutdown() calls start()?
fixed
There is a Callback.Completable class that you can use, rather than manually do this.

This test seems to test an implementation behavior that is IMHO wrong.
If I close NORMAL, and the callback succeeds, then any close after that will fail with a ClosedChannelException and it must not overtake a previous successful close.
From the point of view of the behavior, it breaks the least surprise because I would think that the first successful close is retained, as the second close has failed.

As we discussed in the call, currently abnormal status codes are coded to hard close the connection. So if one is sent in the middle of a close handshake it will interrupt the close handshake and the connection will be closed because of the abnormal status code and not because of the successful close handshake response.
The success or failure of the close callback indicates only whether the close frame could be sent, the onClosed notification tells you the actual reason for the close which could be different for various reasons.
I don't think you need this class, use Callback.Completable instead.
